dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, in March, Forbes revealed that Grayshift's GrayKey tech could crack the latest Android phones, even the Samsung Galaxy S9.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, in March, Forbes revealed that Grayshift's GrayKey tech could crack the latest Android phones, even the Samsung Galaxy S9.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncloaked by Forbes in March, Atlanta-based Grayshift promised governments its GrayKey tech could crack the passcodes of the latest iOS models, right up to the iPhone X.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then Samsung really doubled down on security, right? They kept building up these barriers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then Samsung really doubled down on security, right? They kept building up these barriers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From then on, Apple continued to invest in security in earnest, continually putting up barriers for Grayshift to jump over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But Grayshift still grew—they landed contracts with ICE and the Secret Service, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But Grayshift still grew-they landed contracts with I C E and the Secret Service, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Grayshift continued to grow, however, securing contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Secret Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But now, it seems to have hit a wall. Like, multiple sources say GrayKey can't break passcodes on any Android 12 or above devices anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now, it seems to have hit a wall. Like, multiple sources say GrayKey can't break passcodes on any Android twelve or above devices anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it's only doing partial extractions now—just unencrypted files and some metadata. No more brute forcing through Samsung's protections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's only doing partial extractions now-just unencrypted files and some metadata. No more brute forcing through Samsung's protections.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, GrayKey used brute forcing techniques to guess passcodes and had found a way to get around Apples protections preventing such repeat guesses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And one of Grayshift's founders is actually an ex-Samsung security engineer, which makes this even more telling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And one of Grayshift's founders is actually an ex-Samsung security engineer, which makes this even more telling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And if its impossible for GrayKey, which counts an ex-Apple security engineer among its founders, its a safe assumption few can break iPhone passcodes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, if they can't crack it, probably no one can. Captain John Sherwin from the Rochester Police even confirmed their experience matches that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, if they can't crack it, probably no one can. Captain John Sherwin from the Rochester Police even confirmed their experience matches that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Police officer Captain John Sherwin of the Rochester Police Department in Minnesota said of the claim iOS 12 was preventing GrayKey from unlocking iPhones: Thats a fairly accurate assessment as to what we have experienced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He said something like, "Give it time and a workaround will be developed," though. The cycle just repeats.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He said something like, Give it time and a workaround will be developed, though. The cycle just repeats.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Give it time and I am sure a workaround will be developed ... and then the cycle will repeat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but for now, it's a win for privacy side. The weird part is no one actually knows how Samsung did it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but for now, it's a win for privacy side. The weird part is no one actually knows how Samsung did it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its clear Apple has locked GrayShift out, no one actually knows just how the iPhone maker has done it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft—he's usually great at finding Samsung weaknesses—said he has no idea. Could be kernel protection or configuration-profile restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft-he's usually great at finding Samsung weaknesses-said he has no idea. Could be kernel protection or configuration-profile restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vladimir Katalov, chief of forensic tech provider Elcomsoft, has repeatedly uncovered weaknesses in Apple technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, GrayKey's expanding globally. Wired just reported U.K. police agencies are using it now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, GrayKey's expanding globally. Wired just reported U.K. police agencies are using it now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wiredrevealed last week that a number of U.K. police agencies are now using GrayKeys.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Tim Cook was in Europe this week talking up privacy, which feels timely given all this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Tim Cook was in Europe this week talking up privacy, which feels timely given all this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, Apple chief Tim Cook visited Europe this week, talking up the need for all tech companies to improve privacy for users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like this constant back-and-forth between security and access, huh? Someone's always building a better mousetrap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like this constant back-and-forth between security and access, huh? Someone's always building a better mousetrap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Someone is always building a better mousetrap, whether its Apple or someone trying to defeat device security.

HostA: Right, it's only doing partial extractions now—just unencrypted files and some metadata. No more brute forcing through Samsung's protections.
HostB: And one of Grayshift's founders is actually an ex-Samsung security engineer, which makes this even more telling.
HostA: Yeah, if they can't crack it, probably no one can. Captain John Sherwin from the Rochester Police even confirmed their experience matches that.
HostB: He said something like, "Give it time and a workaround will be developed," though. The cycle just repeats.
HostA: True, but for now, it's a win for privacy side. The weird part is no one actually knows how Samsung did it.
HostB: Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft—he's usually great at finding Samsung weaknesses—said he has no idea. Could be kernel protection or configuration-profile restrictions.
HostA: Meanwhile, GrayKey's expanding globally. Wired just reported U.K. police agencies are using it now.
